article.title: Dorothy_Parker
article.paragraph:
Use mdy datesMay 2013Infobox writerDorothy Parker Dorothy Parker Young Dorothy Parker.jpg200px Dorothy Rothschild {{birth date|1893|8|22|mf[[Long Branch, New Jersey]], U.S. American {{death date and age|mfNew York City, New York, U.S. [[Heart attack]] Author, poet, [[critic]], [[screenwriter]] Poetry, satire, short stories [[American modernism]] Enough Rope, Sunset Gun, Star Light, Star Bright--, [[A Star Is Born (1937 film)|A Star Is Born]] Edwin Pond Parker II (1917–1928)
Alan Campbell (1934–1947)
Alan Campbell (1950–1963) [[Franklin Pierce Adams]], [[Robert Benchley]], [[Colette]], [[Ring Lardner]], [[William Makepeace Thackeray]], [[Elinor Wylie]] [[Candace Bushnell]], [[Maureen Dowd]], [[Nora Ephron]], [[Fran Lebowitz]], [[Amy Sedaris]], [[David Sedaris]], [[Amy Sherman-Palladino]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] {{awd|[[O. Henry Award]]|1929}} {{URL|http://www.dorothyparker.com}} Dorothy Parker(August 22, 1893 June 7, 1967) was an American poet, short story writer, critic andsatiresatirist, best known for herwit, wisecracks, and eye for 20th-century urban foibles.

From a conflicted and unhappy childhood, Parker rose to acclaim, both for her literary output in publications such asThe New Yorkerand as a founding member of theAlgonquin Round Table. Following the breakup of the circle, Parker traveled to Hollywood to pursuescreenwriting. Her successes there, including twoAcademy Awardnominations, were curtailed when her involvement inleft-wing politicsled to a place on theHollywood blacklist.
Dismissive of her own talents, she deplored her reputation as a "wisecracker". Nevertheless, her literary output and reputation for her sharp wit have endured.
article.heading: Early life and education
article.paragraph: Also known as Dot or Dottie, Parker was born Dorothy Rothschild to Jacob Henrycite bookMeadeMarionDorothy Parker: What Fresh Hell Is This?Penguin Books1987New York50-14-011616-8and Eliza Annie Rothschild (ne Marston)Meade 6at 732 Ocean Avenue in the West End village ofLong Branch, New Jersey,cite newshttp://dorothyparker.com/nytobit.htmlDorothy Parker, 73, Literary Wit, DiesThe New York TimesJune 8, 1967AldenWhitmanwhere her parents had a summer beach cottage. Dorothy's mother was of Scottish descent, and her father was of German Jewish descent. Parker wrote in her essay "My Hometown" that her parents got her back to theirManhattanapartment shortly after Labor Day so she could be called a true New Yorker. Her mother died in West End in July 1898, when Parker was a month shy of turning five.Meade 12Her father remarried in 1900 to a woman named Eleanor Francis Lewis.Meade 13Parker hated her father and stepmother, accusing her father of being physically abusive and refusing to call Eleanor either "mother" or "stepmother", instead referring to her as "the housekeeper".cite bookHerrmannDorothyWith Malice Toward All: The Quips, Lives and Loves of Some Celebrated 20th-Century American WitsG. P. Putnam's Sons1982New York780-399-12710-0She grew up on theUpper West Sideand attended aRoman Catholicelementary school at the Convent of the Blessed Sacrament on West79th Street (Manhattan)79th Streetwith sister Helen, despite having aJewishfather andProtestantstepmother.Meade 14(Mercedes de Acostawas a classmate.) Parker once joked that she was asked to leave following her characterization of theImmaculate Conceptionas "spontaneous combustion".Cite bookChambersDianneParker, Dorothy1995The Oxford Companion to Women's Writing in the United StatesWagner-MartinLindaOxford University Presshttp://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subviewHer stepmother died in 1903, when Parker was nine.Meade 16Parker later went toMiss Dana's School for Young LadiesMiss Dana's School, afinishing schoolinMorristown, New Jersey.Meade 27She graduated from Miss Dana's School in 1911, at the age of 18.cite bookKinneyAuthur F.Dorothy ParkerTwayne Publishers1978Boston26–27Following her father's death in 1913, she played piano at a dancing school to earn a livingcite bookSilversteinStuart Y.Not Much Fun: The Lost Poems of Dorothy ParkerScribner1996New York130-7432-1148-0while she worked on her verse.

She sold her first poem toVanity Fair (magazine)Vanity Fairmagazine in 1914 and some months later was hired as an editorial assistant for anotherCond Nast PublicationsCond Nastmagazine,Vogue (magazine)Vogue. She moved toVanity Fairas a staff writer after two years atVogue.Silverstein 13

In 1917, she met and married aWall Streetstockbroker, Edwin Pond Parker IIHerrmann 78(18931933cite newsEdwin P. Parker 2dThe New York TimesAssociated PressJanuary 8, 1933http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res2013-02-28), but they were separated by his army service inWorld War I. She had ambivalent feelings about her Jewish heritage given the strongantisemitismof that era and joked that she married to escape her name.cite bookPenzerOttoThe Vicious Circle: Mystery and Crime Stories by Members of the Algonquin Round TablePegasus Books2007New York99978-1933648675
article.heading: Algonquin Round Table years

link.part: Parker, with Algonquin Round Table members and guests (lr) Art Samuels (editor of ''Harper's'' and, briefly, ''The New Yorker''), Charles MacArthur, Harpo Marx, and Alexander Woollcott

article.paragraph: Her career took off while she was writing theatre criticism forVanity Fair, which she began to do in 1918 as a stand-in for the vacationingP. G. Wodehouse.Silverstein 18At the magazine, she metRobert Benchley, who became a close friend, andRobert E. Sherwood.cite bookAltmanBillyLaughter's Gentle Soul: The Life of Robert BenchleyW. W. Norton & Company1997New York1460-393-03833-5The trio began lunching at theAlgonquin Hotelon a near-daily basis and became founding members of theAlgonquin Round Table. The Round Table numbered among its members the newspaper columnistsFranklin Pierce AdamsandAlexander Woollcott. Through their re-printing of her lunchtime remarks and short verses, particularly in Adams' column "The Conning Tower", Dorothy began developing a national reputation as a wit. One of her most famous comments was made when the group was informed that famously taciturn former presidentCalvin Coolidgehad died; Parker remarked, "How could they tell?"Cite bookCalvin Coolidge2006DavidGreenbergThe American Presidents SeriesTimes Books978-0-8050-6957-09http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/USAparker.htm

Parker's caustic wit as a critic initially proved popular, but she was eventually terminated byVanity Fairin 1920 after her criticisms began to offend powerful producers too often. In solidarity, both Benchley and Sherwood resigned in protest.Altman 1568

WhenHarold RossfoundedThe New Yorkerin 1925, Parker and Benchley were part of a "board of editors" established by Ross to allay concerns of his investors. Parker's first piece for the magazine appeared in its second issue.Silverstein 32Parker became famous for her short, viciously humorous poems, many about the perceived ludicrousness of her many (largely unsuccessful) romantic affairs and others wistfully considering the appeal of suicide.

The next 15 years were Parker's greatest period of productivity and success. In the 1920s alone she published some 300 poems and free verses inVanity Fair,Vogue, "The Conning Tower" andThe New Yorkeras well asLife (magazine)Life,McCall'sandThe New Republic.Silverstein 623File:dotrope.jpgthumbleftCover of the first edition of ''Enough Rope''Parker published her first volume of poetry,Enough Rope, in 1926. The collection sold 47,000 copiesSilverstein 35and garnered impressive reviews.The Nationdescribed her verse as "caked with a salty humor, rough with splinters of disillusion, and tarred with a bright black authenticity".Meade 177Although some critics, notably theNew York Timesreviewer, dismissed her work as "flapperverse",Meade 178the volume helped cement Parker's reputation for sparkling wit.Parker released two more volumes of verse,Sunset Gun(1928) andDeath and Taxes(1931), along with the short story collectionsLaments for the Living(1930) andAfter Such Pleasures(1933).Not So Deep as a Well(1936) collected much of the material previously published inRope,GunandDeathand she re-released her fiction with a few new pieces in 1939 under the titleHere Lies.

She collaborated with playwrightElmer Riceto createClose Harmony, which ran on Broadway in December 1924. The play was well received in out-of-town previews and was favorably reviewed in New York but closed after a run of just 24 performances. It did, however, become a successful touring production under the titleThe Lady Next Door.Meade 138

Some of Parker's most popular work was published inThe New Yorkerin the form of acerbic book reviews under the byline "Constant Reader" (her response to the whimsy ofA. A. Milne'sThe House at Pooh Corner: "Tonstant Weader fwowed up."cite bookParkerDorothyFar From Well, collected in The Portable Dorothy Parker Revised and Enlarged EditionPenguin Books1976New York5180-14-015074-9). Her reviews appeared semi-regularly from 1927 to 1933,Silverstein 38were widely read, and were later published in a collection under the nameConstant Readerin 1970.

Her best-known short story, "Big Blonde", published inThe Bookman (New York)The Bookmanmagazine, was awarded theO. Henry Awardas the best short story of 1929.Herrmann 74Her short stories, though often witty, were also spare and incisive, and more bittersweet than comic.Citation neededSays who?November 2012

She eventually separated from her husband, divorcing in 1928, and had a number of affairs. Her lovers included reporter-turned-playwrightCharles MacArthurand the publisherSeward Collins. Her relationship with MacArthur resulted in a pregnancy, about which Parker is alleged to have remarked, "how like me, to put all my eggs into one bastard."Meade 105She had an abortion, and fell into a depression that culminated in her first attempt at suicide.Silverstein 29

It was toward the end of this period that Parker began to become politically aware and active. What would become a lifelong commitment to activism began in 1927 with the pending executions ofSacco and Vanzetti. Parker travelled toBostonto protest the proceedings. She and fellow Round TablerRuth Hale (feminist)Ruth Halewere arrested, and Parker eventually pleaded guilty to a charge of "loitering and sauntering", paying a $5 fine.Silverstein 44
article.heading: Hollywood
article.paragraph: In 1934, she marriedAlan Campbell (screenwriter)Alan Campbell,Meade 238an actor with aspirations to become a screenwriter. Like Parker, he was half-Jewish and half-Scottish. He was reputed to bebisexualindeed, Parker claimed in public that he was "queeras a billy goat".Citation neededFebruary 2012The pair moved to Hollywood and signed ten-week contracts withParamount Pictures, with Campbell (who was also expected to act) earning $250 per week and Parker earning $1,000 per week. They would eventually earn $2,000 and in some instances upwards of $5,000 per week as freelancers for various studios.Silverstein 40She and Campbell worked on more than 15 films.IMDb name0662213Dorothy Parker
In 1936, she contributed lyrics for the song "I Wished on the Moon", with music byRalph Rainger. The song was introduced inThe Big Broadcast of 1936byBing Crosby.

WithRobert Carson (writer)Robert Carsonand Campbell, she wrote the script for the 1937 filmA Star Is Born (1937 film)A Star is Born, for which they were nominated for anAcademy Awardfor Best WritingScreenplay.cite webA Star is Born (1937)—AwardsInternet Movie Databasehttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0029606/awards2007-09-24She wrote additional dialogue forThe Little Foxes (film)The Little Foxesin 1941 and received another Oscar nomination, with Frank Cavett, for 1947'sSmash-Up, the Story of a Woman, starringSusan Hayward.cite webSmash-Up: The Story of a Woman—AwardsInternet Movie Databasehttp://imdb.com/title/tt0039840/awards2007-09-24

After the United States entered the Second World War, Parker andAlexander Woollcottcollaborated to produce an anthology of her work as part of a series published byViking Pressfor servicemen stationed overseas. With an introduction bySomerset MaughamMeade 318the volume compiled over two dozen of Parker's short stories along with selected poems fromEnough Rope,Sunset Gun, andDeath and Taxes. It was released in the United States in 1944 under the titleThe Portable Dorothy Parker. Parker's is one of only three of thePortableseries (the other two beingWilliam Shakespeareand The Bible) to remain continuously in print.cite bookPublisher's NoteThe Portable Dorothy Parker Revised and Enlarged EditionPenguin1976New York0-14-015074-9

During the 1930s and 1940s, Parker became an increasingly vocal advocate of causes like civil liberties and civil rights, and a frequent critic of those in authority. She reported on theRepublican faction (Spanish Civil War)Loyalist cause in Spainfor the Communist magazineThe New Massesin 1937.Meade 285At the behest ofOtto Katz, a covert Soviet Comintern agent and operative of German Communist Party agentWilli Muenzenberg, Parker helped to found theHollywood Anti-Nazi Leaguein 1936 (which was suspected by the FBI of being a Communist Party front).Koch, Stephen,Double Lives: Stalin, Willi Munzenberg and the Seduction of the Intellectuals, New York: Enigma Books (2004), Revised Edition, ISBN 1-929631-20-0The Hollywood Anti-Nazi League's membership eventually grew to some 4,000 strong. Its often wealthy members' contributions (probably not intended to support Communism) were, in the words ofDavid Caute,Caute, David,The Fellow Travellers: Intellectual Friends of Communism, New Haven: Yale University Press (1988), ISBN 0-300-04195-0"able to contribute as much to [Communist] Party funds as the whole American working class".Willi Mnzenberg's 'Innocents' Clubs'

Parker also served as chair of the Joint Anti-Fascist Rescue Committee. She organized Project Rescue Ship to transport Loyalist veterans to Mexico, headed Spanish Children's Relief and lent her name to many other left-wing causes and organizations.cite bookBuhlePaulDave WagnerRadical Hollywood: The Untold Story Behind America's Favorite MoviesThe New Press2002New York891-56584-718-0Her former Round Table friends saw less and less of her, with her relationship with Robert Benchley being particularly strained (although they would reconcile).Altman 314Parker metS. J. Perelmanat a party in 1932, and despite a rocky start (Perelman called it "a scarifying ordeal")Perelman 171they remained friends for the next 35 years, even becoming neighbors when the Perelmans helped Parker and Campbell buy a run-down farm in Bucks County, Pennsylvania.

Parker was listed as aCommunistby the publicationRed Channelsin 1950.cite webDorothy ParkerR Writer, VersifierRed Channels: The Report of Communist Influence in Radio and TelevisionCounterattackhttp://www.authentichistory.com/1950s/redchannels/redch115.html2007-09-24http://web.archive.org/web/20070807192003/http://www.authentichistory.com/1950s/redchannels/redch115.html2007-08-07TheFBIcompiled a 1,000-page dossier on her because of her suspected involvement in Communism during theJoseph McCarthyMcCarthyera.cite bookKunkelThomasGenius in Disguise: Harold Ross of The New YorkerCarrol & Graf19964050-7867-0323-7As a result, she was placed on theHollywood blacklistby the movie studio bosses. Her final screenplay wasThe Fan (1949 film)The Fan, a 1949 adaptation ofOscar Wilde'sLady Windermere's Fan, directed byOtto Preminger. Her marriage to Campbell was tempestuous, with tensions exacerbated by Parker's increasing alcohol consumption and Campbell's long-term affair with a married woman while he was in Europe duringWorld War II.Meade 327They divorced in 1947,Meade 329then remarried in 1950.Meade 339Parker moved back to New York in 1952, living at the Volney residential hotel at 23East 74th Streeton the Upper East Side.cite journalhttp://books.google.com/books?idJames MalanowskiDead & Famous; Where the Grim Reaper has Walked in New YorkSpyJuly 17, 19592013-04-10From 1957 to 1962, she wrote book reviews forEsquire magazineEsquire,cite webItzkovitzDanielDorothy Rothschild Parker (1893–1967)Jewish Virtual LibraryMay 28, 1998http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/parker.html2005-09-25though these pieces were increasingly erratic owing to her continued abuse of alcohol. She returned to Hollywood in 1961 and reconciled with Campbell. In the next two years, they worked together on a number of unproduced projects. Campbell committed suicide by drug overdose in 1963.Meade 3923
article.heading: Later life and death
article.paragraph: Following Campbell's death, Parker returned to New York City and the Volney residential hotel. In her later years, she would come to denigrate the group that had brought her such early notoriety, the Algonquin Round Table:QuoteThese were no giants. Think who was writing in those days—[[Ring Lardner|Lardner]], [[F. Scott Fitzgerald|Fitzgerald]], [[William Faulkner|Faulkner]] and [[Ernest Hemingway|Hemingway]]. Those were the real giants. The Round Table was just a lot of people telling jokes and telling each other how good they were. Just a bunch of loudmouths showing off, saving their gags for days, waiting for a chance to spring them... There was no truth in anything they said. It was the terrible day of the wisecrack, so there didn't have to be any truth...Herrmann p. 85.

Parker was heard occasionally on radio, includingInformation Please(as a guest) andAuthor, Author(as a regular panelist). She wrote for theColumbia Workshop, and bothIlka ChaseandTallulah Bankheadused her material for radio monologues.cite bookDunningJohnOn The Air: The Encyclopedia of Old-Time RadioOxford University Press19980-19-507678-8

Parker died on June 7, 1967, of amyocardial infarctionheart attackat the age of 73. In her will, she bequeathed her estate to Dr.Martin Luther King, Jr.Following King's death, her estate was passed on to theNAACP.Silverstein 59.Herexecutor,Lillian Hellman, bitterly but unsuccessfully contested this disposition.Meade 413.Her ashes remained unclaimed in various places, including her attorneyPaul O'Dwyer's filing cabinet, for approximately 17 years.Meade 412.
article.heading: Posthumous honors
article.paragraph: In 1988, the NAACP claimed Parker's remains and designed a memorial garden for them outside their Baltimore headquarters. The plaque reads,

quote<arg name="Here lie the ashes of Dorothy Parker (1893–1967) humorist, writer, critic. Defender of human and civil rights. For her epitaph she suggested, 'Excuse my dust'. This memorial garden is dedicated to her noble spirit which celebrated the oneness of humankind and to the bonds of everlasting friendship between black and Jewish people. Dedicated by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. October 28, 1988.{{cite book | last">Hitchens | firstFile:Dorothyparkerlandmark.jpgthumbPlaque at Parker's birthplaceOn August 22, 1992, the 99th anniversary of Parker's birth, theUnited States Postal Serviceissued a 29 U.S. commemorativepostage stampin the Literary Arts series. The Algonquin Round Table, as well as the number of other literary and theatrical greats who lodged there, helped earn the Algonquin Hotel its status as a New York City Historic Landmark. The hotel was so designated in 1987.Cite newsHeller AndersonSusanCity Makes It Official: Algonquin is LandmarkThe New York TimesSeptember 20, 1987http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res2007-10-21In 1996 the hotel was designated a National Literary Landmark by theFriends of LibrariesUSA based on the contributions of Parker and other members of the Round Table. The organization's bronze plaque is attached to the front of the hotel.cite webFriends of Libraries USA1996 dedicationshttp://www.folusa.org/outreach/landmarks-year/1996.php2007-09-13Her birthplace was also designated a National Literary Landmark by Friends of Libraries USA in 2005cite web[[New Jersey Monthly]]The Write StuffFebruary 7, 2008ChristopherHannhttp://njmonthly.com/articles/lifestyle/people/the-write-stuff.htmland a bronze plaque marks the spot where the home once stood.Dorothyparker.com
In 2014, Parker was elected to theNew Jersey Hall of Fame.
article.heading: In popular culture
article.paragraph: Parker was the inspiration for a number of fictional characters in several plays of her day. These included "Lily Malone" inPhilip Barry'sHotel Universe(1932), "Mary Hilliard" (played byRuth Gordon) in George Oppenheimer'sHere Today(1932), "Paula Wharton" in Gordon's 1944 playOver Twenty-one(directed byGeorge S. Kaufman), and "Julia Glenn" in the Kaufman-Moss HartcollaborationMerrily We Roll Along (play)Merrily We Roll Along(1934). Kaufman's representation of her inMerrily We Roll Alongled Parker, once his Round Table compatriot, to despise him.Meade 241She also appeared as "Daisy Lester" inCharles Brackett's 1934 novelEntirely Surrounded.Silverstein 1011

Parker appears as a character in the novelThe Dorothy Parker Murder CasebyGeorge Baxt(1984), in a series of "Algonquin Round Table Mysteries" by J.J. Murphy (2011 ), and in Ellen Meister's novelFarewell, Dorothy Parker(2013).Meister, Ellen (2013)Farewell, Dorothy Parker. Putnam Adult. ISBN 039915907XShe is the main character in a short story, "Love For Miss Dottie," by Larry N Mayer, which was selected by Mary Gaitskill for the collectionBest New American Voices 2009(Harcourt).

She has been portrayed on film and television byDolores SuttoninF. Scott Fitzgerald in Hollywood(1976),citation neededAugust 2013Rosemary MurphyinJulia(1977),citation neededAugust 2013Bebe NeuwirthinDash and Lilly(1999),citation neededAugust 2013andJennifer Jason LeighinMrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle(1994).IMDb title0110588Mrs. Parker and the Vicious CircleFoocite web''Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle''Internet Movie Databasehttp://us.imdb.com/title/tt0110588/2007-09-24Neuwirth was nominated for anEmmy Awardfor her performance, and Leigh received a number of awards and nominations, including aGolden Globenomination.

Parker, along with other figures of the era includingIra GershwinandGeorge Gershwin, is featured as a character in Act 1, Scene 12 of the stage musical version ofThoroughly Modern Millie (musical)Thoroughly Modern Millie, "Muzzy's Party Scene".cite webhttp://www.franciswilsonplayhouse.org/meet_the_cast_MM2008.htmMeet the Cast 'Thoroughly Modern Millie' 2008Francis Wilson Playhouse20082011-07-28http://web.archive.org/web/20110726062950/http://www.franciswilsonplayhouse.org/meet_the_cast_MM2008.htm2011-07-26

Television creatorAmy Sherman-Palladinonamed her production company 'Dorothy Parker Drank Here Productions' in tribute to Parker.cite bookCrusie, Jennifer2007Coffee at Luke's: An Unauthorized Gilmore Girls GabfestPalladino on naming her companyhttp://books.google.com/books?id185http://books.google.com/?idDallasBenBella Books1-933771-17-82012-08-24

Standup comedianJen Kirkmanportrayed Dorothy Parker in an edition of the Dead Authors Podcast at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Los Angeles in 2011.cite web''The Dead Authors Podcast; Chapter 3: Dorothy Parker. Retrieved 2012-08-21''The Dead Authors Podcasthttp://thedeadauthorspodcast.libsyn.com/webpage/chapter-3-dorothy-parker-/comments

A one-woman show,Dorothy Parker's Room Enough For Twostarring Terrie Frankel, was produced in July 1993 at the Groundlings Theatre in Hollywood, California."Parker's Room Enough For Two", Dorothyparkermusical.com. Retrieved 21 December 2013YouTubeTWTf-Jc1Ip4"Terrie Frankel Presents Dorothy Parker's Room Enough For Two". Retrieved 21 December 2013

Prince (musician)Princehas a song entitled "The Ballad of Dorothy Parker", on his albumSign o' the Times.cite web[[Rolling Stone]]74 Prince, 'Sign o' the Times'http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-albums-of-the-eighties-20110418/prince-sign-o-the-times-20110329

In the 1999 filmGirl, Interrupted (film)''Girl, Interrupted'', the character Lisa recites Parker's poem "Resume".cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172493/trivia?ref_''Girl, Interrupted'' (1999) TriviaInternet Movie Database2014-05-03https://web.archive.org/web/20140503213206/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172493/trivia?ref_2014-05-03

The Thrilling Adventure Hourpodcast has Dorothy Parker as a recurring character (as played by Annie Savage) and member of the Algonquin Four. After being struck by a comet, the group gained powers parodyingThe Fantastic Four. Parker gained rock-like skin as a self-proclaimed "rock man", and is the dim-witted muscle of the team. Her catchphrase is "Dorothy Parker smash!"

Tucson actress Lesley Abrams wrote and performed the one-woman showDorothy Parker's Last Callin 2009 in Tucson, Arizona at the Winding Road Theater Ensemble"Shaken Not Stirred"Retrieved 2014-07-12.and reprised the role at the Live Theatre Workshop in Tucson in 2014."'Last Call' an energetic reflection of Dorothy Parker's lifeRetrieved 2014-07-12.The play was also selected to be part of the Capital Fringe Festival in DC in 2010."Dorothy Parker's Last Call"Retrieved 2014-07-12.
Her poem "Threnody" was recorded by Annifrid Lyngstad, of ABBA fame.

Lyrics taken from her book of poetryNot So Deep as a Wellwere, with the authorization of the NAACP,"The composer wishes to thank the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for authorizing the use of Dorothy Parker's works."Retrieved 2015-05-21.used by Canadian singer Myriam Gendron to create a folk album of the same name."Myriam Gendron inspired by Dorothy Parker poems"Retrieved 2015-05-21.
